awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award:Examination of Multiple Chronologies
awd_abstract_narration:
Absolute time, or chronology, is fundamental to interpret the past. However, the disregard for how past societies actually experienced time results in a discrepancy between generalized models of socio-cultural change and the diverse experience of life’s rhythms, thus perpetuating the creation of dehumanized histories. How people organize around life’s rhythms, whether as members of a generation or as a society responding to broader environmental or socio-cultural challenges, profoundly impacts the decisions made in the present, thus shaping the course of actions in the long-term. Archaeology is well positioned to solve this tension between absolute and lived time by offering a long-term perspective on the unfolding of human experience. This project will undertake research that uses radiocarbon dating to investigate people’s lived experience of time in past communities.The project also speaks to a wider anthropological conversation regarding the understanding of time as a social construct and the artificial separation between society and “clock time”. The research includes broad scientific collaboration and encourages training in archaeological science among students and scholars.

The project will investigate how to identify different dimensions of lived time from material remains, which will offer a new approach for archaeologists studying socio-cultural changes in the unwritten past. This archaeological study, covering a remarkable duration, offers an ideal opportunity to analyze how alternative lived rhythms contribute to socio-cultural stability in the long-term. Contrary to previous approaches, this work will interpret the radiocarbon-based chronology of sites by referring to real lifespans, such as those derived from age at death and generational distance observed in collective burials, thus humanizing the history of single sites. This humanization of chronology will also consider alterations in climatic stability, as demonstrated by previous studies, and the interruption of daily life as documented by layers of abandonment in site stratigraphies. Relevant samples suitable for high-resolution radiocarbon analysis will be collected from museum collections and ongoing excavations. In addition to producing a robust radiocarbon dataset, the project will ultimately enhance the possibilities of archaeological chronology and help close the gap between short-term and long-term perspectives.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Chronologies are fundamental to historical and social inquiry. Without them, it would be impossible to order events, establish contexts of causality, and disclose the speed and direction of change. But different societies build chronologies differently, shaped by the way they experience time and understand its rhythms. And these differences have implications for how we develop chronologies today.

Archaeology is an ideal position to solve the dichotomy between absolute and lived time thanks to its traditional focus on the unfolding of human experience in the long term. This project reexamines archaeology's engagement with time, chronology, and narrative by focusing on the organic lives dated by radiocarbon through the application of high-resolution Bayesian chronological modeling. This approach enhances the value of radiocarbon dates as independent measurements and their potential for accessing the intrinsic temporalities of past human communities, enriching temporal plots alongside object-based chronologies. As a case study, the research employed the archaeological and chronometric evidence associated with the Early Bronze Age in the South Caucasus.

During the funded period, the co-PI conducted fieldwork in Armenia and Georgia to acquire new 14C samples to expand and complement the existing radiocarbon corpus. The selection included both freshly excavated and archival materials that presented potential for radiocarbon study. Sample acquisition and characterization in the field occurred via the direct engagement with experts based at Armenian, Georgian, EU-, and US-based institutions, including archaeologists, bioarchaeologists, archaeobotanists, and zooarchaeologists. Further screening of radiocarbon samples took place with the assistance of experts in dendrochronology at Cornell University. Radiocarbon dating took place at the W.M. Keck AMS Facility of UCI, where the co-PI prepared the samples for AMS dating under the supervision of the laboratory director and staff.  

The project delivered theoretical, methodological, and empirical outcomes. Theoretically, the project engaged with the history of archaeology in the South Caucasus by reflecting on the temporal assumptions embedded in the construction of the past, with specific insights into Bronze Age chronopolitics within Soviet and post-Soviet traditions. This reflection explicitly fleshed out how archaeology has integrated radiocarbon dating into discourses on time and narrative, bridging theory and archaeological science by reflecting on the creation of 'objective' data within existing knowledge structures. More broadly, this reflection speaks to the need to critically approach the role of technologies within social and humanistic sciences. Methodologically, the project applied Bayesian chronological modeling and evaluated samples through flexible chronometric hygiene. This meant that the project maximized the chronometric utility of available samples in the light of preservation and retrieval contingencies: for instance, fragmentary charcoal was assessed for dendrochronological potential and, when possible, integrated within Bayesian models to establish temporal constraints (termini post quos) through wiggle-match sequences. Sub-sampling of skeletal remains integrated with age-estimates were also included as sequences in Bayesian model to refine temporal estimates for human behavior and archaeological activity. This methodology was coherent with the theoretical focus on organic life cycles in chronology. Empirically, the project produced 73 new 14C dates, enriching the existing record for the South Caucasus both quantitively and qualitatively, enhancing the scientific value of existing archives. The new data clarified the sequence of settlements within the sampled regions, rectifying existing assumptions based on problematic data, but also offering more robust estimates for chronological comparisons across Southwest Asia during the Early Bronze Age. Bayesian models generally resulted in narrower estimates for the sampled EBA sites, thus reshaping our understanding of contemporaneity amongst sites. The project also resulted in the creation of a relational database designed for the easy retrieval of 14C dates and related information to enable Bayesian chronological modeling. This database will serve as an initial prototype for a regional radiocarbon repository, while also advancing practitioners' understanding of best practices for the management of chronological data.

Intellectually, the project developed an important critique of archaeological epistemology, examining the theories and methods that the discipline traditionally employs to create both narratives of the past and meaning in the present. The project's focus on organic lives instead of inorganic materials (only) encouraged the creation of narratives about human actions, and not just human products. The research design incorporated potential broader impacts at every step of the project. Fieldwork aimed at sample collection and selection ensured knowledge exchange between the co-PI and specialists in Armenia, Georgia, the EU, and the USA, resulting in newly forged collaborations and building local capacity. The co-PI's training in radiocarbon dating through laboratory participation at UCI contributed to her doctoral curriculum and positioned her in an ideal position to foster conversations bridging theory and archaeological sciences among emerging scholars. Preliminary observations and reflections resulting from this project have been presented at the SAA, EAA, and in invited talks at workshops on the archaeology of the South Caucasus. Finalized theoretical and data-specific discussions are currently in preparation for peer-review journals.
